results.title: Alert!
results.brief_description: A series of incidents demonstrating the need for accident prevention. People on dangerous jobs are aware of the risks and keep their minds on their work, but passers-by and workers who are worried or inclined to day-dream, need to remember that nearly all accidents happen through thinking of something else. A quarter of all accidents happen through the job being done the wrong way; untidily, without safety devices or too fast. Film closes by re-emphasising the need to be constantly alert.

results.title: Alejandro Mamani: a case study in culture and personality
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Alejandro Mamani is a leader in his Bolivian mountain community, but he is an old man and believes himself possessed of evil spirits. Many remedies are tried to rid him of these spirits, from traditional forms of exorcism to sleeping tablets, but all attempts fail and after making his will he eventually commits suicide. Did he go mad or did he simply make use of his culture to leave life, once he saw there was no further use for him and his affairs were in order? Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Alcoholism: who gets hurt?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Questions, Answers.”.
Shows the problems of a son of an alcoholic as he vacillates between shielding his father and trying to find his own place among his peers. Uses an extract from the Disney production “Follow me boys” made in 1966.

group_siblings.title: Being right: can you still lose?
group_siblings.creator_credit: Walt Disney Educational Media Company

results.title: Alcoholism
results.brief_description: The film portrays alcoholism as a mental health problem and as an illness that can respond to treatment. Demonstrates that the causes of this illness are imbedded personality difficulties often relating back to the early formative years of the victim’s childhood. The film discusses different forms of alcoholism and the different treatment required for each type. The role of Alcoholics Anonymous is covered and a plea made for increased public facilities for the treatment of alcoholics.

results.title: Alcohol: the problem with drinking
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmanian Film Corporation, Alcohol and Drug Dependency Board of Tasmania and Sherry James
results.brief_description: The problem of teenage/adolescent drinking. Discusses some of the reasons why they drink, their attitude towards alcohol, and some problems associated with drinking. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Alcohol: the first decision
results.creator_credit: King Screen Productions and Don Dickerson
results.brief_description: Surveys what young people are confronted with when deciding whether or not to drink, including seeing their parents drink, seeing advertisements for liquor in newspapers, magazines, and on billboards, and hearing alcoholism made a subject for levity on radio and television.

results.title: Alcohol: how much is too much
results.creator_credit: Quartet Films, West, Frank Gardonyi, Alan Capps, Ingvar Grimsgaard and Lou Lilly
results.brief_description: An open-minded film which discusses social and physiological effects of alcohol. It is particularly designed for elementary grades. The film considers alcohol through such facts as its abuse as a drug, and its physiological effects on the brain and other parts of the human body. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Alcohol: a new focus
results.creator_credit: American Educational Films, Directions Unlimited and Noel Nosseck
results.brief_description: Points out that everyone, at some time in his life, has to decide whether or not to drink, how much to drink and under what circumstances. Looks at the historical facts of the temperance debate, drinking traditions and effects of alcohol on the body. Builds up a case against unwise drinking habits. Narrated by James Brolin.
